topic.title: Eventing Examples
topic.shortdesc: Examples of how to use the Eventing framework.

section.title: Prerequisites
section.p: The following prerequisites must be observed:

ul.li: Creation of a Metadata bucket: Functions stores artifacts and checkpoint information in a bucket. Set up a single bucket, across the cluster, as a metadata bucket. Ideally, this bucket should not be used for storing information from any other application. For the following examples, this metadata bucket is named metadata.
Creation of Source and Target buckets: Create two buckets and name them source and target respectively. These buckets can be either of the type Couchbase or Ephemeral. Default settings can be used.

section.title: Example 1
section.p: Problem: When a document is created, one of the attributes of the document needs to be translated to a new value, and the same needs to be captured for lookups, to be used later. In this case, the sample document (mentioned below), has twi IP strings that need to be converted to numerals, so that range-scans can be performed for a given new IP.

Solution: Create an OnUpdate handler in a function that listens to changes/mutations in a source bucket. The source bucket will contain the sample document. A target bucket needs to be defined, to store the enriched document. The OnUpdate handler invokes the user-defined function, named get_numip_first_3_octets, on the IP string that returns an integer for a given IP string. This function is computed for both ip_start and ip_end; and the original document is appended with two new attributes, and inserted into the target bucket. The original document in the source bucket is not changed.

ol.li: Click on ‘Add Function’.
Choose the Source Bucket that contains the sample document.
Specify a ‘metadata’ bucket; mentioned in the Prerequisites.

Specify a function-name and a readable description.
Function name: enrich_ip_nums
Function description: Enrich a document, converts IP Strings to Integers that are stored in new attributes.
‘Settings’ can contain the standard defaults.

Bindings: Create a binding for ‘target’ bucket as ‘tgt’:
Choose the ‘target’ bucket from the name dropdown.
Type ‘tgt’ (without quotes) in value textbox.
Click ‘Next: Add Code’ and paste the code specified in the Sample Code Section, below.
Click on ‘Eventing’ in the left navigation bar: this takes you to the Functions summary screen.
Click on the ‘Deploy’ button for the ‘enrich_ip_nums’ function. Choose ‘Everything’ in the Feed Boundary dropdown. The function should be ‘deployed’ and ‘running’ in a few seconds.

Check the ‘target’ bucket for the enriched document, with the following structure inserted.
{ "country": "AD", "ip_end": "5.62.60.9", "ip_start": "5.62.60.1", "ip_num_start": 87964673, "ip_num_end": 87964681 }

section.title: Example 2
section.p: Problem: When a document expires from a source bucket, archive the document’s value in another target bucket.

Solution: As the Function Service does not have an OnExpiry handler, create a timer that will execute a few minutes before expiry. We create a docTimer in the OnUpdate handler. The docTimer will be executed two minutes before expiry; and this callback, associated with the docTimer, will retrieve the document’s value from the source bucket, and store in the target bucket. The original document in the source bucket is not changed.
A sample document with a TTL set for 10 minutes from creation-time can be created using the following python script:
section.codeblock:
from couchbase.cluster import Cluster from couchbase.cluster import PasswordAuthenticator import time cluster = Cluster('couchbase://localhost:8091') authenticator = PasswordAuthenticator('test', 'asdasd') cluster.authenticate(authenticator)
cb = cluster.open_bucket('logs') print("Lets insert a document") cb.upsert('demo-key', 'demo-value') print "Doc Value:", cb.get('demo-key').value print "Document inserted. Lets set its TTL" cb.touch('demo-key', ttl=10*60)

ol.li: Click on ‘Add Function’.
Choose the Source Bucket that contains the sample document.
Specify a ‘metadata’ bucket; mentioned in the Prerequisites.
Specify a function-name and a readable description. Function name should be add_timer_before_expiry. Function description should be Create a timer two minutes before expiry of a document.
‘Settings’ can contain the standard defaults.

Bindings:
Create a binding for the source bucket as src. Choose the source bucket from the name dropdown, and type src in the value textbox.
Create a binding for the target bucket as tgt. Choose the target bucket from the name dropdown, and type tgt in the value textbox.
Click ‘Next: Add Code’, and paste the code specified in the Sample Code Section, below.
Click on ‘Eventing’ in the left navigation bar: this takes you to the Functions summary screen.
Click on the ‘Deploy’ button for the ‘add_timer_before_expiry’ function. Choose ‘Everything’ in the Feed Boundary dropdown. The function should be ‘deployed’ and ‘running’ in a few seconds.
Check the ‘target’ bucket for one inserted document.
